moves.1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. exd5 exd5 4. d4 Nf: Having an extra opening for the bishop is really unnecessary.
moves.5... Nc6: More usual for me would be Bd6.
moves.6... Bd6 7. Bg5: This costs valuable time when white needs to castle.
moves.7... O-O 8. Bg2 Re8+ 9. Be3 Ng4 10. Qd2: This backward pawn will be white's undoing.
moves.12. O-O Nf5 13. Re1 h5: Since Black's pieces are aimed toward the kingside, this makes sense.
moves.14. Qd3 c5: 14. ... h4 is also good.  15. g4 h3  16. Bxh3 Nh4 with threats and complications.  17. Nxh4?? Qxh4 forks two pieces.  18. e4 dxe4 19. Rxe4 Rxe4 20. Qxe4 Qh4 with powerful threats.
moves.15... dxc4: Now white should try to hang on with Qd2.
moves.16... Nxe3 17. Qe2: 17. Qc3  is just slightly better because black would like to be able to play cxd4 followed by Bc5.
moves.17... Bd7: Bf5, Bg4 and cxd4 are also good.
moves.18. Nc3: This is the wrong square because after cxd4 threatening the knight, white's options are more limited.  Nbd2 is better.
moves.18... cxd4 19. Nxd4 Bc5: Suddenly things are horrid for white.  Now 20. Nb3?? Nxg2+ 21. Kxg2 Bc6+.  If instead 21. Nxc5  Rxe2  22. Rxe2 Qb6 will eventually win because the pins and material advantage.
moves.20. Qd3: 20. Qd2 doesn't seem to be any better after Nxg2.
moves.20... Nxg2: Now if 21. Kxg2 Bc6+ 22. Kf1 Qd7! puts white in a world of hurt.
moves.21. Rxe8+ Bxe8 22. Kxg2: 22. Nce2 might prolong the agony longer.

players: rravanne  vs. John Coffey, Chess Player at Lar
